Fig. 1 Photocatalytic activity of the catalysts under UV light irradiation: (a) MB degradation by bare TiO2,15c, 30c, 60c and 90c; (b) MB degradation by bare TiO2, 0.5i, 1i, 1.5i and 5i; (c) MB degradation by bare TiO2, 1i, and 60c; (d) 5 times recovery of 60c; (e) phenol degradation by bare TiO2, 1i, and 60c determined with UV–vis spectroscopy; (f) phenol degradation by bare TiO2, 1i, and 60c determined with HPLC. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns of bare TiO2, 1i, recovery 1i, recovery 60c and 60c. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 SEM images of 60c (a) and 1i (d); Cu element mapping of 60c (b) and 1i (e); EDS images of 60c (c) and 1i (f). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Low resolution TEM images: (a) 60c, (b) 1i; high resolution TEM: (c) 60c, (d) 1i, (e) reused 60c, (f) reused 1i. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms and Barret–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) pore-size-distribution plots (inset): (a) 60c; (b) 1i; (c) bare TiO2. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 H2-TPD patterns of 60c, 1i and TiO2. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 The mechanism diagram of degrade of organic pollutants on Cu/TiO2. Fig. 7 Stable and highly efficient Cu/TiO2 nanocomposite photocatalyst prepared through atomic layer deposition Feng Gao a Jie Jiang a Liyong Du a Xinfang Liu b Yuqiang Ding a ⁎ a International Joint Research Center for Photoresponsive Molecules and Materials, School of Chemical and Material Engineering, Jiangnan University, 1800 Lihu Road, Wuxi 214122, PR China International Joint Research Center for Photoresponsive Molecules and Materials School of Chemical and Material Engineering Jiangnan University 1800 Lihu Road Wuxi 214122 PR China b Henan Key Laboratory of Function-Oriented Porous Materials, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Luoyang Normal University, Luoyang 471934, PR China Henan Key Laboratory of Function-Oriented Porous Materials College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Luoyang Normal University Luoyang 471934 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A stable and highly efficient Cu/TiO2 nanocomposite photocatalyst was successfully synthesized through atomic layer deposition (ALD). A series of spectroscopic tests confirmed that subnanoscale Cu particles were conformally dispersed on TiO2, and that TiO2 surface states could be modified by controllable Cu particles. The photodegradation of methylene blue and phenol under ultraviolet light was used as a probe for investigating the photocatalytic efficiency of the photocatalyst, and Cu-loaded TiO2 prepared through ALD was discovered to exhibit high and stable activity compared with that prepared through impregnation. These results prove that ALD is an effective strategy for improving the photocatalytic activity of TiO2, and that Cu/TiO2 is a photocatalyst that can effectively remove organic pollutants. Keywords Cu/TiO2 nanocomposite Atomic layer deposition (ALD) Photocatalytic activity 1 Introduction Photocatalysis has been widely investigated and its process has been developed since the 1970s [1,2]. TiO2 has been a focus of research because of its potential applications in dye-sensitized solar cells, photocatalysis, sensors, lithium batteries, and biomedicine. Moreover, it is nontoxic, abundant, and affordable and has excellent optical properties [3–5]. However, electron–hole recombination occurs rapidly on bare TiO2, and the material has a wide band gap, which severely limits its applicability in photocatalysis [6,7]. To overcome these limitations, various approaches have been adopted, including photosensitization [8], metal cation doping [9], and metal loading [10]. Recent research has proven that loading TiO2 with atoms of a noble metal (Pt, Au, Pd, and Ag) effectively enhances the photocatalytic activity of TiO2 by preventing electron–hole recombination [11–14]; however, the cost of noble metals is high; thus, loading TiO2 with Cu or CuOx (to form Cu/TiO2 or CuOx/TiO2) instead through impregnation, magnetron sputtering, or electroless plating has drawn much attention in the field of photocatalysis because Cu and CuOx are abundant and nontoxic and have a high optical absorption coefficient [15–18]. A previous study found that a nanosized and well-dispersed Cu-loaded TiO2 photocatalyst with high surface area has higher catalytic performance than CuOx-loaded TiO2 and bare TiO2 [15]. More recently, catalysts prepared at the atomic level (single atom catalysts [SACs]) have been reported to show excellent performance, and the deposition of subnanometer metal particles on nanomaterials can significantly enhance catalytic activity [19,20]. Atomic layer deposition (ALD) is a technique that achieves digital control over the amount of deposited material through sequential self-limiting surface reactions, which enables technical requirements to be met [21]. Thus, ALD can accurately deposit subnanoscale particles on nanoparticles and even in their pores [22]. In previous studies, catalysts synthesized using ALD had uniform surfaces, and ALD did not alter the original specific surface area or pore structure, and it could realize extraordinary reproducibility and favorably controlled subnanoparticles composition and atomic-level thickness [23–25]. Using ALD to deposit subnanoparticle Cu on the surface of nano-TiO2 particles may result in more efficient preparation of Cu/TiO2. In this study, we prepared highly efficient Cu/TiO2 catalysts containing highly dispersed surface Cu sites by using ALD. The catalyst structure and composition were systematically analyzed using energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), field-emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method, atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) and H2 temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD). Photocatalytic activity was evaluated through methylene blue (MB) and phenol degradation. Remarkably, the catalysts exhibited highly stable photocatalytic activity, even after five uses. Photocatalysts synthesized using ALD may play a pivotal role in the application of heterogeneous photocatalysis in the near future. The present study findings provide a comprehensive understanding of the effects of metallic Cu on anatase TiO2 and photocatalysis using the material. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Catalysts 15c, 30c, 60c, and 90c prepared through ALD To obtain a suitable ALD process, Cu was deposited onto a SiO2 wafer by using a previously described method [26]. The optimized ALD process was as follows: [Cu(sBu-amd)]2 was used as the Cu precursor and was maintained at 100 °C. H2 was employed as the reductant, and N2 was used as the carrier gas. The substrate temperature was maintained at 185 °C. One deposition cycle consisted of a [Cu(sBu-amd)]2 pulse, N2 purge, H2 pulse, and N2 purge. Using the same optimized ALD process, Cu was deposited on TiO2 nanoparticles (size: 10–25 nm, anatase type) over 15, 30, 60, or 90 cycles; the Cu/TiO2 catalysts prepared are thus referred to as 15c, 30c, 60c, and 90c, respectively. 2.1.2 Catalysts 0.5i, 1i, 1.5i, and 5i prepared through impregnation Wet impregnation was performed using a previously described method [15] as follows: TiO2 nanoparticles (3 g, size: 10–25 nm, anatase type) were added to 15 mL of 0.5 wt% Cu(NO3)2 solution. The mixture was sonicated for 30 min and then stirred for 2 h. The resultant homogenous mixture was dried overnight and calcined at 500 °C for 5 h to obtain CuO/TiO2 nanoparticles. Reduction of the CuO/TiO2 nanoparticles under a flow of 10% H2/N2 at 300 °C for 3 h produced TiO2-supported copper metal photocatalysts (Cu/TiO2; 0.5i). Using a similar procedure, catalysts 1i, 1.5i, and 5i were prepared using Cu(NO3)2 solution concentrations of 1, 1.5, and 5 wt%, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The morphology and chemical composition of the samples were determined using a field-emission SEM system (Hitachi S-4800) equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscope (EDAX GENESIS XM2 SYSTEM 60X) for chemical mapping. TEM was conducted on a JEOL JEM-2100 Plus operated at 200 kV. XRD patterns were obtained using an X-ray diffractometer (BRUKER AXS D8 ADVANCE) equipped with α Cu radiation source (k = 0.154 nm). Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) analysis was conducted on an ASAP 2020 M P. The acquired spectra were analyzed using the Bruker software suite and data in the Inorganic Crystal Structure Database. AAS was performed on an A3F instrument with a dominant wavelength range of 190–900 nm. H2-TPD was performed at AutoChem Ⅱ 2920 system. The sample (100 mg) was ﬁrst reduced in a 10% H2/N2 ﬂow (30 m L/min) at 300 °C for 1 h. After that, the sample was cooled to 50 °C and saturated with a 10% H2/N2 ﬂow for 0.5 h, then purged with a N2 ﬂow for 1 h to eliminate the excess of H2. The TPD experiments were carried out in a N2 stream (30 m L/min) from 50 °C to 650 °C at a ramp of 5 °C/min, and the amount of H2 uptakes during the reduction was measured. 2.3 Photoactivity testing The photocatalytic activity of the catalysts was determined by testing the photodegradation of MB dye and phenol in an aqueous solution using the following procedure. The catalyst (10 mg) was spread uniformly on a 100-mL photoreactor vessel; thereafter, 100 mL of MB (0.02 mg/mL) or phenol (0.01 mg/mL) solution was added to the photoreactor. Before photoirradiation, the system was magnetically stirred for 30 min in the dark to achieve adsorption–desorption equilibrium between the photocatalyst and MB (or phenol). The photoreactor containing the suspension was then irradiated under a 400 W high-pressure mercury lamp without cutoff filters. Every 5 min, 1 mL of the suspension was pipetted out and immediately separated using centrifugation. Subsequently, 1 mL of the supernatant was diluted to 5 mL. The residual concentration of MB (or phenol) in the supernatant was analyzed using an ultraviolet (UV)–visible–nearinfrared spectrophotometer (Xiamen, PHILIPS, China) at the characteristic wavelength of MB and phenol (664 nm and 270 nm, respectively). Besides, to investigate the degradation process of phenol, the solution of degradative phenol was analyzed by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC, 1525 u) equipped with an isocratic gradient pump, a 20 u L injection circuit and a variable wavelength UV detector. C18 (250 mm-length × 4.6 mm-ID×5 um-particle size) was used in the sample analysis with a mobile phase mixture of water 60% (v/v) and methanol 40% (v/v) at the flow rate of 1 mL·min−1. The wavelength of the detector was set at 270 nm. The degradation rate was calculated as follows: Degradation Rate = A 0 − At A 0 × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Performance analysis of Cu/TiO2 catalysts Cu-loaded TiO2 photocatalysts (Cu/TiO2) prepared through impregnation, thus far, have been proven to be more catalytically active than those prepared through magnetron sputtering and electroless plating [15]. For comparison, photocatalysts 0.5i, 1i, 1.5i, and 5i—with different Cu loadings—were prepared through impregnation [15]. SACs have demonstrated to show excellent performance, and the deposition of metal particles on nanomaterials can significantly enhance the catalytic activity of the materials [19,20]. ALD is a promising technique for the deposition of subnanoscale particles on nanoparticles [21]. The deposition of Cu on SiO2 and SiN4 has been extensively investigated in the microelectronics field. We believe that highly efficient Cu/TiO2 catalysts containing highly dispersed subnanoscale Cu particles can be prepared using ALD. Cu was deposited on TiO2 nanoparticles (size: 10–25 nm, anatase type) using the optimized ALD process and using impregnation; deposition was performed for 15, 30, 60, and 90 cycles, yielding the Cu/TiO2 catalysts 15c, 30c, 60c, and 90c, respectively. The photocatalytic performance of the photocatalysts was evaluated by using the degradation of MB and phenol under UV light as probes. The changes in the MB and phenol degradation rate versus the irradiation time for different catalysts are presented in Fig. 1 . To achieve optimal photocatalytic activity, the number of ALD cycles, which is associated with the degree of Cu particle deposition on TiO2 particles, was investigated. The results revealed that catalysts 60c and 1i exhibited the highest photocatalytic activity of the ALD-obtained catalysts and impregnation-obtained catalysts, respectively (Fig. 1a, b). As expected, bare TiO2 had the lowest catalytic efficiency compared with the catalysts prepared using ALD and impregnation. Approximately 95% of MB was degraded within 45, 25, 15 min when bare TiO2, 1i, and 60c were used as the photocatalysts under UV irradiation, respectively. A comparison of the MB degradation rate of the prepared photocatalysts is presented in Fig. 1c. The degradation rate achieved using 60c was three times greater than that using bare TiO2 and 1.5 times greater than that using 1i. During the experiment, the catalysts were reused for five successive runs without any cleaning procedure being performed. Remarkably, the MB degradation rate achieved using 60c was largely unaffected after five successive runs (Fig. 1d). In order to verify the suitable range of the catalyst for degradation of substrate, we conducted a related experiment on phenol. The UV–vis spectroscopy was convenient and widely used [27,28], herein the degradation of phenol was firstly monitored by UV–vis spectroscopy and the results were summarized in Fig. 1e. As expected, Fig. 1e viewed that 60c also showed faster degradation rate than 1i and bare TiO2 and the phenol degradation rate can reach 90% within 25 min. It is known that varieties of intermediates are produced during the degradation of phenol, such as catechol, hydroquinone, and benzoquinone, and these intermediates have absorption at 270 nm. Therefore, the HPLC was used to determine the degradation of phenol and the results showed (Fig. 1f) that the degradation rate can reach 98% in 25 min and almost 100% in 30 min catalyzed by 60c. Meanwhile in the process of phenol degradation, the intermediate catechol, hydroquinone, and benzoquinone were produced and further destroyed. In general, from these MB and phenol degradation probe tests, we can conclude that the catalysts prepared using ALD performed more favorably than those prepared through impregnation, which is in agreement with the findings provided in the literature [26]. 3.2 Characterization of the catalysts Photocatalysts 60c and 1i, which were found to have the highest catalytic performance, were characterized and compared with bare TiO2 to gain a comprehensive understanding of the relationship between material morphology and photocatalytic activity. The crystal phase of photocatalyst components is widely recognized to influence the light absorption of the photocatalyst. To determine the crystal structure of photocatalytic nanoparticles synthesized using ALD and impregnation, the prepared samples were characterized using XRD. The XRD patterns of the as-prepared Cu/TiO2 products and recovered catalysts are displayed in Fig. 2 . The diffraction peaks at 2θ = 25.3°, 37.8°, 48.1°, 53.9°, 55.1°, 62.7°, and 75.0° corresponded to reflections from the (101), (004), (200), (105), (211), (204), and (215) planes, respectively, of TiO2 in the anatase phase (JCPDS file: 21-1272). For the ALD-prepared Cu/TiO2 sample (60c), two weak diffraction peaks at 43.4° and 50.6° were observed, which corresponding to reflections from the Cu (111) and (004) planes, respectively (JCPDS file: No. 65-9743); these peaks were due to the low weight loading of metal nanoparticles on TiO2. However, no typical diffraction peaks corresponding to Cu were observed for the catalysts synthesized using impregnation, possibly because the Cu nanoparticles loaded on TiO2 through impregnation were not shaped. Additionally, the XRD patterns indicate that the Cu deposited through ALD and impregnation did not modify the anatase phase of TiO2, because the cell parameters of TiO2 were unchanged in all samples. The particle size of a photocatalyst affects the dispersibility of the photocatalyst and thus affects its efficiency [29,30]. Typical scanning electron micrographs of 60c and 1i are presented in Fig. 3 . The SEM images of TiO2 products with different Cu loadings (Fig. 3a, d) depict roughly spherical particles. The particles in 60c and 1i were of uniform size and were well dispersed. Elemental mapping images indicate that all catalysts contained elemental Cu, and using EDS mapping images, the proportion of Cu was roughly quantified (Fig. 3b, e, c, f). AAS was employed to accurately measure the amount of copper in the products. The Cu content of 60c and 1i was identified as 0.12 and 0.32 wt%, respectively, which was consistent with the results of EDS. TEM images were used to further clarify and intuitively determine the morphology of the photocatalysts and the valence state of the element. Low-magnification TEM images (Fig. 4 a, b) indicate that 60c and 1i had a smooth and rough surface, respectively. This was speculated to be because elemental Cu was present in the form of subnanoparticles on TiO2 forming 60c (according to the ALD loading mechanism), whereas elemental Cu was present as nanoparticles on TiO2 forming 1i (the dark-field TEM image reveals that Cu nanoparticles were dispersed on the surface of TiO2 nanoparticles). Two phases—Cu and TiO2—can be clearly observed in the high-resolution TEM images of freshly made and reused Cu/TiO2 catalysts (Fig. 4c–f). The lattice spacings of Cu/TiO2 were 0.35 and 0.21 nm, corresponding to the (101) plane of anatase and (111) plane of metallic copper, respectively. Furthermore, from the regional distribution of the two types of lattice fringes, Cu morphology could be inferred to be present. In Fig. 4c, the lattice fringes of Cu are distributed uniformly around the TiO2 particles, whereas in Fig. 4d, the lattice fringes of Cu are irregularly distributed in the area corresponding to the TiO2 particles. Fig. 4c–f perfectly illustrates the impact of manufacturing method on the structure. No change was detected in Cu after the photoreaction had occurred. Catalysts with a higher specific surface area have more reaction sites; additionally, the pore structure of a catalyst affects the contact between activity sites and reactants. Fig. 5 presents liquid nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms and the corresponding Barret–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) pore size distribution plots of the catalysts. The results indicated that 60c, 1i and bare TiO2 had a type-III adsorption–desorption isotherm with H3 hysteresis loops that jumped in N2 adsorption branches starting at a very high relative pressure (P/P0 ≈ 0.85). The BET specific surface areas of 60c, 1i and bare TiO2 were calculated as 159.1, 64.0 m2/g and 161.8, respectively, and the BJH pore size distribution plots revealed a single broad distribution of pore size (100–900 Å), which can be attributed to intercrystallite voids among the stacked nanoparticles. The pore structure and particle size of the catalyst synthesized using ALD did not change. However, the pore structure and particle size of the catalyst synthesized using impregnation drastically changed. Cu probably acted as a binder that allowed multiple TiO2 nanoparticles to agglomerate during the calcining step of the impregnation method. As displayed in Fig. 6 , the desorption of H2 occurred in a wide range of temperature (100–650 °C) over the reduced catalysts. The only one desorption peaks can be observed on 1i and 60c, as expected, TiO2 has no obvious peak. Meanwhile, the amount of H2 adsorption of 60c is much larger than that of 1i. According to literature [31], the peak represents the desorption of hydrogen from the Cu particles. For the Cu/TiO2 catalyst in this paper, the amount of desorption of H2 is positively correlated with exposed surface area of Cu of the catalyst. By combining H2-TPD results with AAS results, 60c has a lower Cu content than 1i but has a larger exposed surface area of Cu, which can reflect the greater dispersion of the Cu component in the 60c. Comparing the activity of 60c and 1i from the perspective of exposed Cu surface area, the catalyst has a larger exposed Cu surface area is conducive to higher catalytic activity. This result may be due to the larger interaction area between Cu subnanoparticles (formed by ALD) and TiO2 particles, which is more conducive to receiving electrons and forming the degradation center of organic matter. 3.3 Reaction mechanism UV illumination for the photoactivation of bare TiO2 excites electrons in the TiO2 valence band, causing their migration to the conduction band and resulting in positively charged holes that promote the photocatalytic reaction [32]. The Cu-loaded TiO2 composite photocatalysts synthesized using both ALD and impregnation demonstrated excellent efficiency in photocatalytic degradation. Their high photocatalytic activity can be attributed to Cu, which acts as an electron receiver and thus decreases the recombination rate of electron–hole pairs in TiO2. In an aqueous solution, photogenerated electrons rapidly transfer to Cu and immediately react with oxygen to form superoxide free radicals, at the meantime the positively charged holes act on the hydroxyl groups to form hydroxyl radicals, these free radicals degrade MB and phenol into small inorganic molecules [32]. Compared with the other catalysts synthesized using the same method, 60c and 1i exhibited the highest catalytic performance. For 60c, this catalytic performance was possibly because of the suitable thickness of the Cu layer. UV light could penetrate the Cu layer and provide sufficient reaction sites. For the series of impregnation-prepared catalysts, the size and number of Cu nanoparticles on the surface of 1i were the most favorable for the penetration of UV light, again providing numerous reaction sites to enhance the catalytic efficiency of TiO2 (Fig. 7 ). Overall, the efficiency of the most efficient catalyst synthesized using ALD was 1.5 times greater than that of the most efficient catalyst synthesized using impregnation. Catalyst 60c was probably the most efficient catalyst synthesized using ALD because it had a uniform surface and a determined composition, thus providing more reactive sites. The photocatalysts with a higher BET surface area afforded more access to organic molecules, which was beneficial to their photocatalytic reactivity. Because the BET surface area of 60c was significantly greater than that of 1i, 60c had more reaction sites. A major problem posed by transition metal nanoparticles in the zero-oxidation state is their sensitivity. Researchers usually employ surface passivation and a protective agent (poly(N-vinyl-2-pyrrolidone)) to protect Cu nanoparticles or films with a zero-valence state [33]. Therefore, the use of Cu as a catalyst is greatly restricted. However, 60c retained a value state and its original crystal structure even after five degradation cycles, which indicates that the catalyst is photocatalytically stable. This is because copper oxide generated in the reaction can be reduced to Cu nanoparticles by accepting photogenerated electrons generated through UV light irradiation of the TiO2 [15]. 4 Conclusion A stable and highly efficient Cu/TiO2 nanocomposite photocatalyst was successfully synthesized using ALD. A series of spectroscopic tests confirmed that subnanoscale Cu particles were conformally dispersed on TiO2, and that the TiO2 surface states could be modified by controllable Cu particles. The photodegradation of MB and phenol was used as a probe for investigating the catalytic activity of the photocatalyst, and the results indicated that Cu-loaded TiO2 prepared through ALD exhibited high and stable activity compared with that prepared through impregnation. These results demonstrate that ALD is an effective strategy for improving the photocatalytic activity of TiO2, and that Cu/TiO2 is a photocatalyst that can effectively remove organic pollutants. Acknowledgments We gratefully acknowledge financial support of this work by the National Natural Science Foundation of China-Henan joint fund (No. U1604143) and the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities (JUSRP51627B). coredata.dc:description: A stable and highly efficient Cu/TiO2 nanocomposite photocatalyst was successfully synthesized through atomic layer deposition (ALD). A series of spectroscopic tests confirmed that subnanoscale Cu particles were conformally dispersed on TiO2, and that TiO2 surface states could be modified by controllable Cu particles. The photodegradation of methylene blue and phenol under ultraviolet light was used as a probe for investigating the photocatalytic efficiency of the photocatalyst, and Cu-loaded TiO2 prepared through ALD was discovered to exhibit high and stable activity compared with that prepared through impregnation. These results prove that ALD is an effective strategy for improving the photocatalytic activity of TiO2, and that Cu/TiO2 is a photocatalyst that can effectively remove organic pollutants.
coredata.dc:title: Stable and highly efficient Cu/TiO2 nanocomposite photocatalyst prepared through atomic layer deposition
